Mr. B. WEBSTER, Sole Lessee and Manager, Old Brampton.

TheSUITEofDRAWINeROOWS

*' Old Heads and Young Hearts,'' by Mr. Dion BoUrcieault,
was produced at this theatre last night with the most entire
and unqualified success. It is full of amusing incident and
lively bustle which never allow the interest in the development of the plnn and story of the play to flag. The dialcgne
is remarkable for what is*called " smartness ;" it frequently
rises into t h . brilliant and sparkling, and no wher. limps or
hangs €re. Every joke and sarcasm came as a decided bit.
and the laughter and applause which followed them wer.
both hearty and sptntnneous. The characters were, moreover, all individually well drawn and nicely contrasted, and
the parts were strongly cast. The piece closes with the
marriage of the lovers in the most approved form, and the
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. The scenery
and dresses were \ery splendid. Nothing could be in better
taste than Lord Pompion's drnwing-roorn. The piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Globe.
The comedy is put splendidly upon the stage, and may be
pronounced perfectly successful,—Sell'i Weekly Messenger.
Every scene produced something unexpected, and very
cleverly contrived.—Court Gazette.
The Haymarket is at length set up with a new comedy
that is likely to attract for a time. Old Heads and Young
Hearts has hit the taste of the town. Smartly written,
cleverly performed, and handsomely put on the stage—
vivacious enough to be entertaining— this last production of
Mr. Bourckault was received with acclamations on the first
night. It is written up to comedy pitch.— The Spectator.
That long-sought philosopher's stone, a five-act comedy,
has at length been found ; Mr. Webster is the fortunate
discoverer. The Muse, that would not he bribed with the
tempting purse of five hundred golden guineas, has, of hei
own free-will, granted the thing wanted. Mr. Dion Bourcicanlt is the favored agent through whom she has mad. this
present to the world. ' Old Heads and Young Hearts' is the
name of this dramatic prodigy ; which, thougli haply many
imbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title to
the name, we must in justice pronounce it to lie a legitimate
comedy. There is within it that sterling stuff ef the head, if
not of the heart, which qualifies it to take its station amongst
our standard dramas. The characters are developed with
great skill; the language is sparkling and vivacious; the
cast of characters having been as strong as it possibly cottld
be, and the mite-enscent
being most admirable, it was
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
had been set upon it. The greatest praise is undoubtedly due
to Mr. Webster for his selection of this successful com.dv,
and for the liberal manner in which he has produced it. It
is likely to have an immense run.—Court Journal.
W e may at once suy that the success of the piece was
most complete and decided. Old Heads and Young Hearts
has earned its appellation. Mr. Bourcicault's main stay has
been equhtque, bon mots, quaint views of the motives and
springs of fashionable life, and smart repartee ; materials of
which he has a great abundance at command, and uses them
\ery skilfully and pleasantly—sometimes rising even above
the refined witticisms of the School for Scandal, and rarely
falling below the broad drolleries of Colraan's five-act
extravaganzas—Allot,

Mr. Boitrcicault, whose freshness of spirit delighted the
town when he presented his London Assurance, produced a
new comedy here on Monday, under the title of Old Heads
and Young Heaits, and it met with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause was elicited by the acting,
and scenic arrangements; but the play itself possesses the
elements of success : it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h . applause given
to the new comedy was hearty and universal.—Belts' New
Weekly Messenger.
Old Heads and Young Hearts was played for the second
time last night, and again received with rapturous applause
by a crowded audience. W e have much pleasure to affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will add much to the
author's reputation as a dramatist. It evinces a most accurate
knowledge of stage effect. 1 he comedy is admirably brought
out, and the performers exerted themselves to the utmost.
The comedv, we are certain, will have a long and prosperous
career.— Theatrical Observer.
The production of new and original piece, is so laudable
to a managerial attempt, that Mr. Webster deserves every encouragement for his efforts to develop living and native
talent, and gratify the public by presenting them with dram as
that, being of the time, reflect the time, and show t h . body
of the age, its form and prMRure. In subservience to this
end, the comic muse is. perhaps the most availnble in itself,
and certainly the best adapted to the resources of the HayMarket Theatre. Nowhere elsa can comedy be so well
repiesent.d. ' O l d Heads atld Young Hearts prepared the
plav-goer for antithesis! anil repartee in the dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e were heartily glad,
however, that the audience, recognized the manager's good
intentions, and justified the applause with which the curtain
eventually fell on the new play.— The Athemmwm.
The pretensions of the comedy and its author, in this
instance, seem, to depend, in a very great degree,
on the dialogue, and to this we are disposed willingly to
accord no small amount of merit. His dialogue is showy,
superficial, occasionally brilliant. He surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allusion or pointed phrase. The audience
were kept skilfully in suspense till the very close. T h e
performers exerted themselves zealously to secure the success
of the play, and this they undoubtedly achieved. As a
whole it went off well, and was uproariously applauded at
the conclusion. The piece is admirably produced, and has
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in giving reality and
effect to .very scene. We feel bound to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants the belief
that it will have a run that will repay the manager for its production ; while the acting of such performers as are engaged
in ii must ensure the development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
Whatever name is given to the entertainment in five acts
produced here, its reception does not admit of doubt. It is
greatly successful. W e did not see it until Thursday, when,
in despite and defiance of the fog, we found the enjoyment
of a large audience clear and indisputable. Laughter was
hearty and unrestrained, and the curtain fell to peals of prolonged applause. The arrangements of the scene are alt in
the best possible taste.—Examiner,

To-morrow, the Theatre will be Closed by Order «f the LORD CHAMBERLAIN.

The SUITE oi DRAWING ROOMS
GII U Z N B E L O D G E .
The Nevo'Comedy, e n t i t l e d '"OLD HEADS AND YOUNG HEAKTS,' is ptibllslied In W . t . t e r c
N a t i o n a l Acting D r a m a , a n d m a y b e h a d i n t h e T h e a t r e , a n d of a l l Booksellers.
P r i c e T w o Shillings a n d ixpencc.
Also, " CJESAB. DE BA3EAN " P r i o . S d , a n d " T h e MYSTERIOUS STRANGER," P r i c e Is.

" O l d Heads and Young Hearts," by Mr. Dion Bourcicault,
•was produced at this theatre last night with the most entire
and unqualified success. It is full of amusing incident and
lively bustle which never allow the interest in the development of the plan and story of the play to flag. The dialogue
is remarkable for what is called " smartness ;" it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling, and no where limps or
hangs fire. Every joke and sarcasm came as a decided hit,
and the laughter and applause which followed them were
both hearty and spontaneous. The characters were, moreover, all individually well drawn and nicely contrasted, and
the parts were strongly cast. T h e piece closes with the
marriage of the lovers in the most approved form, and the
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. The scenery
and dresses were very splendid. Nothing could be in better
taste than Lord Pompion's drawing-room. The piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Globe.
The comedy is put splendidly upon the stage, and may be
pronounced perfectly successful.—Belfs Weekly Messenger.
Every scene produced something unexpected, and very
cleverly contrived.—Court Gaxelte.
The Haymarket is at length set up with a new comedy
that is likely to attract for a time. Old Heads and YoungHearts has hit the taste of the town
Smartly written,
eleverly performed, and handsomely put on the stage—
vivacious enough to be enteitaining— this last production of
Mr. Bourcicault was received with acclamations on the first
night. It is written up to comedy pitch.—The Spectator.
That long-sought philosopher's stone, a five-act comedy,
has at length been found ; Mr. Webster is the fortunate
discoverer. The Muse, that would not be bribed with the
tempting purse of five hundred golden guineas, has, of her
own free-will, granted the thing wanted Mr. Dion Bourcicault is the favored agent through whom she has made this
present to the world. * Old Heads and Young Hearts' is the
name of this dramatic prodigy ; which, though Imply many
imbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title to
the name, we must in justice pronounce it to be a legitimate
comedy. There is within it that sterling stuff of the head, if
not of the heart, whieh qualifies it to take its station amongst
our standard dramas. The characters are developed with
great skill; the language is sparkling and vivacious; the
cast of characters having been as strong as it possibly could
be, and the mi*e~en-8cene being most admirable, it was
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
had been set upon it. The greatest praise is undoubtedly due
to Mr. Webster for his selection of this successful comedy,
and for the liberal manner in which he has produced it. It
is likely to have an immense run.—Court Journal.
W e may at once say that the success of the piece was
most complete and decided. Old Heads and Young Hearts
h a s earned its appellation. Mr. Bourcicaults main stay has
been equivoque, bon mots, quaint views of the motives and
springs of fashionable life, and smart repartee; materials of
which he has a great abundance at command, and uses them
very skilfully and pleasantly—sometimes rising even above
t h e refined witticisms of the School for Scandal, and rarely
falling below the broad drolleries of Colroan's five-act
extravaganzas.- Atlas.

Mr. Bourcicault, whose freshness of spirit delighted the
town when he presented his London Assurance, produced a
new comedy here on Monday, under the title of Old Head*
and Young Heatts, and it met with decided success. We.
admit that much of the applause was elicited bv the acting,
and scenic arrangements; but the play itself possesses the
elements of success : it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e applause given
to the new comedy was hearty and universal.—Belts Neur
Weekly Messenger.
Old Heads aud Young Hearts was played for the second
time last night, and again received with rapturous applaus.
by a crowded audience. W e have much pleasure to affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will add much to fit.
author's reputation as a dramatist. It evinces a most accurate
knowledge of stage eflect. The comedy is admirably brought
out, and the performers exerted themselves to the utmost.
The comedy, we are certain, will have a long and prosperous
career.— Theatrical Observer.
The production of new and original pieces is so laudable
to a managerial attempt, thai Mr. Webster deserves every encouragement for his efforts to devejop living and native
talent, and gratify the public by presevdin'g them with dramas
that, being of the time, reflect the time, and show the body
of the age, its form and pressure. In subservience to this
end, the comic muse is, perhaps, the most available in itself,
and certainly the best adapted to tne resources of the HayMarket Theatre. Nowhere else can comedy be so well
represented. ' Old Heads and Young Hearts prepared the
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in the dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
We were heartily glad,
however, that the audience recognized the manager s good
intentions,and justified the applause with which the curtain
eventually fell on the new play.— The Atheneeum.
The pretensions of the comedy and its author, in this
instance, seem, to depend, in a very great degree,
on the dialogue, and to this We are disposed willingly t o
accord no small amount of merit. His dialogue is showy,
superficial, occasionally brilliant. He surprises and please,
too, by a happy allusion or pointed phrase. The audience.
were kept skilfully in suspense tilt the very close. T h .
performers exerted themselves zealously to secure the success,
of the play, and this they undoubtedly whieved. As a
whole it went off well, and m
uproariously applauded a t
the conclusion. The piece is admirably produced, and has
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in giving reality and
effect to every scene. We feel bound to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants the belief
that it will have a run that will repay the manager for its production ; while the acting of such performers as are engaged
in it must ensure the development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
Whatever name is given to the entertainment in five acts
produced here, its reception does not admit of doubt. It is
greatly successful. W e did not see it until Thursday, when,
in despite and defiance of the fog, we found the enjoyment
of a large audience clear and indisputable. Laughter was
hearty and unrestrained, and the curtain fell to peals of prolonged applause. T h e arrangements of the scene are all in.
the best possible taste.—Examiner,

" Old Heads and Young Heaits,'' by Mr. Dion Bourcicault,
was produced at this tlieatrc last night with the most entire
and unqualified success. It is full of amusing- incident and
lively bustle which never allow the interest in the development of the plan and story of the play to flag. The dialogue
is remarktible for what is'called " smartness ;" it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling, and no where limps or
hangs fire. Every joke and sarcasm came as a decided hit,
and the laughter and applause which followed them were
b«th .hearty and spontaneous. The characters were, moreover, all individually welldrawrt and nicely contrasted, and
the parts were strongly cast. The piece closes with the
marriage of the lovers in the most approved form, and the
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. The scenery
and dresses were very splendid. Nothing could be in better
taste than Lord Fompion's drawing-room. The piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Globe.
The comedy is put splendidly upon the stage, and may be
pronounced perfectly successful.—Sell's It'eekly Messenger.
Every scene produced something unexpected, and very
cleverly contrived.—Court Gaxette.
i
The'Hay market is at length set up with a new comidy
that is likely to attract for a time. Old Heads and Young
Hearts has hit the taste of the town. Smartly written,
cleverly performed, and handsomely put on the stage —
vivacious enough to be entertaining— this last production of
Mr. Boureicault was received with acclamations on the first
night. It is written up to comedy pitch.—The Spectator.
That long-sought philosopher's stone, a five-act comedy,
has at length been found; Mr. Webster is the fortunate
discoverer. The Muse, that would not be bribed with the
tempting purse of five hundred golden guineas, has, of her
own free-will, granted the thing wanted. Mr. Dion Bourcicault is the favored agent through whom she has made this
present to the world. ' Old Heads and Young Hearts' is the
name of this dramatic prodigy; which, though haply many
imbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title to
the name, we must in justice pronounce tt to ne a legitimate
comedy. There is within it that sterling stuff of the head, if
not of the heart, whiah qualifies it to take its station amongst
our standard dramas. The characters are developed with
great skill- the language is sparkling and vivacious; the
cast of characters having been as strong as it possibly could
be, and the mise-en-scene being most admtraole, it was
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
had been set upon it. The greatest praise is undoubtedly duo
to Mr. Webster for his selection of this successful comedy,
and for the liberal manner in which h e has produced it. It
is likely to have an immense run.—Cmtrt Journal.
W e may at once say that the success of the piece was
most complete and decided. Old Heads and Young Hearts
has earned its appellation. Mr. Bourcicault's main stay has
been eqtiircqve, bon mots, quaint views of the motives and
springs of fashionable life, and smart repartee ; materials of
which he has a great abundance at command, and uses them
very skilfully and pleasantly—sometimes rising even above
therefined witticisms of the School for Scandal, and rarely
felling below the broad dtolleries of.Colman's five-act
extravaganzas.—Atlas.

Mr. Bourcicault, whose freshness of spirit delighted the
town when he presented his London Assurance, produced a
new comedy here on Monday, under the title of Old Iff ads
and Young Hearts, and it met wijh decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause was elicited by the acting,
and scenic arrangements; but the play itself possesses the
elements of success : it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. The applause given
to the new comedy was hearty and universal.—Belts Neitf
Weekly Messenger.
Old Haads and Young Hearts was played for the second
time last night, and again received with rapturous applause'
by a crowded audience. We have much pleasure to affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will add much to the
author's reputation as a dramatist. It evinces a most accurate
knowledge of stage effect. The comedy is admirably brought
out, and the performers exerted themselves to the utmost.
The comedy, we are certuin, will have a long and prosperous
career.— Theatrical Observer.
The production of new and original pieces is so laudable
to a managerial attempt, that Mr. Webster deserves every en
couragement for his efforts to develop living and native
talent,and gratify the public by presenting them with dramas
that, being of the time, reflect the time, and show the body
of the age, its form and pressure. In subservience to this
end, the comic muse is, perhaps, the most available in itself,
and certainly the best adapted to the resources of the HayMarket Theatre. Nowhere eise can comedy be so well
represented. ' O l d Heads and Young Hearts prepared the
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in the dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e were heartily glad,
however, that the audience recognized the manager s good
intentions, and justified the applause with which the curtain
eventually fell on the new play.— The Athenreutn.
The pretensions of the comedy and its author, in this
instance, seem, to depend, in a very great degree,
on the dialogue, and to this we are disposed willingly to
accord no small amount of merit. His dialogue is showy,
superficial, occasionally brilliant. Ha surprises and please,
too, by a happy allusion or pointed phrase. The audience
were kept skilfully in suspense till the very close. T h e
performers exerted themselves zealously to secure the success
of the play, and this they undoubtedly achieved. As •
whole it went off well, and was uproariously applauded at
the conclusion. The piece is admirably produced, and h a s
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in giving reality and
effect to every scene. We feel bound to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants the belief
that it will have a run that will repay the manager for its production ; while the acting of such performers as are engaged
in it must ensure the development ot whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
Whatever name is given to the entertainment in five acts
produced here, its reception does not admit of doubt. It is
greatly successful. We did not see it until Thursday, when,
in despite and defiance of the fog, we found the enjoyment
of a large audience clear and indisputable. Laughter was
hearty and unrestrained, and the curtain fell to peals of prolonged applause. The arrangements of the scene are all in
the best possible taste.-r-£;ra/nt«er.

OPINIONS of the PRESS.

" Old H*adg and Young1 Hearts,'' by Mr.Dion Bourcir-ault,
was produced at thi« theatre last night with the mg»» ••*»»
*nd unqualified success- It is full of amustntr •".ident and
lively bustle which never allow * • •"•i»ere»t in the deveiopment of the plan and story of the play to flag1. The dialogue
is remarkable for what is called " smartness ;" it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling, and no where limps or
bangs fire. Every joke and sarcasm come as a decided hit,
and the laughter and applause which followed them were
both hearty and spontaneous. T h e characters were, moreover, all individually w*ll drawn and nicely contrasted, and
the parts were strongly cast. The piece closes with the
marriage of the lovers in the most approved form, and the
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. The scenery
and dresses were very splendid. Nothing eould be in better
test, than Lord Pompion's drawing-room. The piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Globe.
The comedy is put splendidly upon the stage, and may be
pronounced perfect! v successful.—Belft Weekly Messenger.
Every s e e n , produced something unexpected, and very
eleverly contrived,—Court Gazette.
The "Haymarket is at length set u p with a new comedy
that is likely to attract for a time. Old Heads and Young
Hearts h*s hit th» taste of the town. Smartly written,
oleverly performed, and handsomely put on the stage —
vivacious enough to b e entertaining— this last production of
ifr. Bourcicattlt was received with acclamations on the first
night. I t is written up to comedy pitch.—The Spectator.
That long-sought philosopher's stone, a five-act comedy,
has at length been found; Mr. Webster is the fortunate
discoverer. T h e Muse, that would not be bribed with t h .
tempting purse of five hundred golden guineas, has, of her
own free-will, granted the thing wanted. Mr, Dion Ikmrcieaalt is die favored agent through whom she has made this
present to the world. ' Old Heads and Young Hearts' is t h e
i of this dramati< prodigy; which, though haply many
imbned with very critical prejudices may dispute its titkt to
til. name, we must in iustice prommsw. it to lie . legitimate
comedy. T h a r , is within it that -Wrung staff of t h . head, if
not of t h . heart, which qualifies it to take ha station amongst
our standard dramas. The characters a m developod with
great skill; t h e language is sparkling and vivacious; the
mist of characters having been as strong as it possibly could
be, and t h . mise-en~tcene being roost admirable, it was
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and universal, denoted that the seal uf public approval
hmi h o e . set upon it. T b . greatea* «raise t* undoubtedly due
to Mr. Webster for his selection of tfci. aaecessfal comedy,
and for the liberal manner in which h e has produced it. I t
is likely to have a . immense run.—Court JountaJ.
W e may a t oaee any that the success of the piece was
meet compUt. and decided. Old Heads and Young Hearts
has earned its appellation. Mr. Bourcicault's main stay has
been equivoque, ban wwts, quaint views of the motives and
-prings of fashionable life, and smart repartee; materials of
w m ^ s M a m s . g r e a t abundance at eommand, and uses them
, U J »easa%U> Mad fltam»otly---ioiae»iine» rising even above
the refined witticisms of the ISehool for Scandal, and rarely
falling below the broad drolleries of t Colman's five-act

Mr. Bourcicault, whose freshness of spirit delighted t h e
!"«,» ,. l.,... |UB p_„.„^,.j u . r , ~ ' .. 4*,*r*„ms*, nroduced a
new comedy here on Monday, under the title of but J / V - J .
and Young Hearts, and it met with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause was elicited by the acting,
and scenio arrangements; but the play itself possesses t h e
elements of success ; it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. T h e applause given
to the new comedy was hearty and universal.—Belts Nev>
Weekly Messenger.
Old Heads and Young Hearts was played for the second
time last night, and again received with rapturous applause
by a crowded audience. W e have much pleasure to affirm
that it is very excellently written, and will add much to the
author's reputation as a dramatist. I t evinces a most accurate
knowledge of stage effect. The comedy is admirably brought
out, and the performers exerted themselves to the utmost.
The comedy, we are certain, will have a long ami prosperous
career.—Theatileal Observer.
•:•
The production of new and original pieces is so laudable
to a managerial attempt, that Mr., webipter deserves every en
couragement for his efforts to -develop living and native
talent, and gratify the public by presenting them with dram as
that, being of tile time, reflect the time, and show the body
of the age, its form and pressure. In. subservience to this
end, the comic muse is, perhaps, the. most available in itself,
and certainly the best adapted to the resources of the HayMarket Theatre. Nowhere else can comedy be so weH
represented. ' Old Heads and Young Hearts prepared the
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in the dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters
W e were heartily glad,
however, that the audience recognised the manager s good
intentions, and justified*the applause with which the curtain
eventually fell on the new play.— The Athenmum.
T h e pretensions of the comedy . m l its author, in this
instance, seam, to depend, in a very great degree,
on the dialogue, and to this we are disposed willingly to
accord no small amount of merit. His dialogue is showy,
superficial, occasionally brilliant. H . surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allusion or pointed phrase. T h e audience
were kept skilfully in suspense till the very close. The
performers etferted themselves zealously to secure the success
of the play, and this they undoubtedly achieved. As a
whole it went off well, a n d was uproariously applauded at
the conclusion. The piece is admirably produced, and baa
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid in giving reality ami
effect to every scene. W e feel bound to add that the report
we heist of its nightly reception since, warrants the belief
that it will have a run that will repay the manager for its production ; while the acting of such performer* as are engaged
to it must ensure t h e development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist,
Whatever name is given to the entertainment in five acta
produced here, i t s reception does not admit of doubt. I t is
greatly successful. W e did not see it until Thursday, whan,
in despite and defiance of the fog, we fount! the enjoyment
of a large audience clear and indisputable. Laughter was
hearty and unrestrained, and A . curtain fell to peals of prolonged applause. T h . arrangements of the s e e n , are alt m
the beat possible taste.—Examiner.

and unqualified success. I t is full of amusing incident and new comedy here on Monday, under the title of Old Heads
lively bustle which never allow the interest in the develop- and Young Hearts, and it met with decided success. W e

rises into the brilliant and sparkling, and no where limps or elements of success : it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
hangs fire. Every joke and sarcasm came as a decided hit, bustling incidents and dramatic effects. The applause given

OPINIONS of the PRESS.

1
Old HenHs and ^ out g Heat Is,'' by Ifr Won Bomciiault
«as pre-ducccl at tliis tlieatro last night viitii die most entire
and unqualified success. It is full of amusing incident and
lively bustle which never allow the interest in the development of the plan and story of the play to flag. The dialogue
iS remarkable for What ischrled " smartness ;*' it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling, and no where limps or
hangs €re. Every joVe and sarcasm came as a decided hit,
and the laughter and applause which followed them were
both hearty and spontaneous. T h e characters were, moreover, all individually well drawn and nicely contrasted, and
the parts were strongly cast. The piece closes with the
marriage of the lovers m the most approved form, and the
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. The scenery
and dresses were very splendid. Nothing could be in better
taste than Lord Pompion's drawing-room. The piece will
doubtteS* b«»e-« long run.-rGVooe.
The comedy is put splendidly upon the stage, and may be
pronounced perfectly successful.—HtU's IVeekh) Messenger.
Every scene produced something unexpected, and very
cleverly contrived.—Court Oaxette.
The Hay market is at length set up yiith a new cijnud}
that is likely to attract for a time. Old Heads and Young
Hearts has hit the taste of the town. Smartly written,
cleverly performed, and handsomely put on the stage—
vivneicus enough to be entertaining- this last production of
Mr. Bourcicault was received with acclamation* on the lirst
night. It is written up to comedy pitch.—fit* Spectator.
That long-sought philosopher's stone, a fi»e-aet comedy,
has at length been found ; Mr. Webster is the fortunate
discoverer. The Muse, that would not be bribed with the
tempting pvirse of five hundred golden guineas, has, of her
own free-will, granted the thing wanted
Mr. Dion Bourci
caiilt is the fevered agent through whom she has made this
present to the world. ' Old Heads and Young Hearts 1 is the
name of this dramatic prodigy ; which, though haply many
imbued with very critical prejudices may dispute its title to
the name, we must in justice pronounce It to be a legitimate
. comedy. There is within it that sterling stuff of theTiead, if
not of the heart, which qualifies it to take its station amongst
our standard dramas. T h e characters are developed with
great skill; the language is sparkling and vivacious; the
ctt*t of characters having been as strong as it possibly could
be, and the mise-en-srene being most ndmirntile, it was
entirely and unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and universal, denoted that the seal of public approval
had been set upon it. The greatest praise is undoubtedly due
to Mr. Webster for his selection of this successful comedy,
and for'the liberal manner in which he has produced it. It
is likely to have an immense run.— Court Journal.

Mr. Rourcicault, whose fieshncss of spirit delighted the
town when be piesenled his London Assurance, produced a
new comedv here en Monday, under the title of Old Heads
and Young Hearts, and it met with decided success. W e
admit that much of the applause was elicited by the acting,
and scenic arrangements; but the play itself possesses the
elements of success : it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic efTects. T h e applause given
to the new comedy was hearty and universal.—Bell's New
Tf eekly Messenger.
The production of new and original pieces is so laudable
to a managerial attempt, that Mr. Webster deserves every eu
couragement for bis efforts to develop living and native
talent,and gratifj the public by presenting them witbdromas
that, being of the time, reflect the time, and show the body
of the age, its form and pressure. In subservience to this
end, the comic muse is, perhaps, the most available in itself,,
and certainly the best adapted to the resources of the HayMarket Theatre. Nowhere else can comedy be so well'
repiesented. ' O l d Heads and Young Hearts1, prepared the
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in the dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e were heartily glad,
however, that the audience recognized Ihe managers good
intentions, and justified tiie applause with which the curtain
eventually fell on the new play.— The Atkena>wn.
The pretensions of the comedy and its author, in this
instance, seem, t o depend, in n very great degree,
OH the dialogue, and to this we are disposed willingly to
accord no snail amount of merit. His dialogue is sTiowy,
superficial, occasionally brilliant. He surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allusion or pointed phrase. The audience
were kept skiifully in suspense till the very close. T h e
peiformers exerted themselves zealously to secure the success
of the play, and this they undoubtedly achieved. As a
whole it went off well, and was uproariously applauded at
the conclusion. The piece is admirably produced, and has
every adventiti.us appliance fitted to aid in giving reality and
effect to every scene. We feel bound to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants the belief
that it will have a run that will repay the manager for its production ; while the acting of such performers as are engaged
in it must ensure the development of whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
Whatever name is given to the entertainment in five acts
produced here, its reception iloes not admit of doubt. It is
greatly successful. We did not see it until Thursday, when,
in despite and defiance of the fog, we found the enjoyment
of a large audience clear and indisputable. Laughter was
hearty and unrestrained, and the curtain fell to peals of prolonged applause. The arrangements of the scene are all ia
the best possible taste.—Examiner.

GRACIOSA & PERCINET,

THB TEMPLB,
T H E COUNTESS O F POMFION's BOUDOIR.

3^

* Old Heads and Young Hearts,'' by Mr. Dion Bo.rcic.tlIt
was produced at this theatre last night vvitn the most entire
and unqualified success. It is full of amusing incident qnd
lively bustle which never allow the interest in the development of the plan and story of the play to flag'. The dialogue
is remarkable for wlmt is called "smartness ;" it frequently
rises into the brilliant and sparkling, and no where limps or
hangs €re. Every joke and sarcasm came as a decided hit,
and the laughter and applause which followed them were
both hearty and spontaneous. The characters were, moreover, all individually well drawn and nicely contrasted, and
the parts were strongly cast. The piece closes with the
marriage of the lovers in the most approved form, and the
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. The scenery
and dresses were very splendid. Nothing could be in better
taste than Lord Pompion's drawing-room. The piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Globe.

O P I N I O N S o f time PRESS.

" Old Heads iititl You;!"; Hearts,*' by Mr. VJion Botircknult,
Vias produced at tins theatre lust night »iti. llie mosteiittre
and unqualified success It is full of amusing incident and
lively bustle which never allow the interest in the development of the plan and story of the play to flag. The dialogue
is remarkable for what is called " smartness ;" it frequently
rises into the hrilliant and sparkling, and no where limps or
hangs fire. Every joke and sarcasm came as a decided hit,
and t i e laughter and applause which followed them were
both learty and spontaneous. The characters were, moreover, all individual!v well drawn and nicely contrasted, and
the parls were strongly cast. The piece closes with the
marriage of the lovers in the most approved form, and the
curtain fell amid a perfect furor of applause. The scenery
and dresses were very splendid. Nothing could be in better
taste than Lord Tompion's drawing-room. The piece will
doubtless have a long run.—Globe.
The comedy is put splendidly upon the stage, and may be
pronounced perfectly successful.—Bell's Jl'ceity Messenger.
Every scene produced something unexpected, and very
clcverlv contrived.— Court Gazette,
The May market is at length sit tip with a new comidv
that is !tk"clv to attract for a time. Old Heads and Young
Hearts has hit the taste of the town. Smartly Written,
cleverly performed, and handsomely put on the stage—
vivacious enough to bo entertaining— this last production of
Mr. Bourci) ault was received with acclamations on the first
night. It is written up to comedy pitch.—3L*fc» Spectator.
That long-sought philosopher's stone, a i'tve-act comedy,
has at length been found ; Mr. Webster is the fortunate
discoverer. The Muse,that would not be bribed with the
templing purse of five hundred golden guineas, has, of her
own free-will, granted the thing wanted. Mr. Dion Bourci
cauit is the fanned agent through whom shu has made this
present to the world. ' Old Heads and Young Hearts' is the
name of this dramatic prodigy j which, though haply many
imbued with verv critical prejudices mav dispute its title to
the name, we must in justice pronounce it to be a legitimate
comedy. There is within it that sterling stuff of the head, if
not of the heart, which qualities it to take its station amongst
our standard dramas. The ehaiacters are developed with
great skill; the language i« sparkling and vivacious; the
cast of character* having been a s strong as it possibly could
be, and the mise-rn-scene being most admirable, it was
entirely mid unequivocally successful. Plaudits, long and
loud and universal, denoted that (be seal of public approval
had heen tft upon it. The greatest praise is undoubtedly due
to Mr. Webster for his selection of this successful comedy,
and for the liberal manner in which he has produced it. I t
is likely 1O hkve an immense run.—Court Journal,

Mr. Bi creicault, whose fieshness of spirit delighted the
(own when he presented his London Assurance, produced a
new corned} here on Monday, under the title of Old Bead*
and Young Heai>s. and it met with decided success. W e
f'dmit that much of the applause was elicited by the acting,
and scenic arrangements; but the play itself possesses the
elements of success ; it is lively, witty, and amusing—full of
bustling incidents and dramatic effects. The applause given
to the new comedy was hearty and universal.—BelPf Keiv
Weekly Messenger.
The production of new and original pieces is so laudable
to a managerial attempt, that Mr. Webster deserves every en
coimigernent for his eiiorts to develop living and native
talent, and gratify the public by presenting them with dram as
that, being of the time, reflect the time, and show the body
of the age, its form and pressure. I n subservience to this
end, the comic muse is, berhaps, the most available in itself,
and certainly the best adopted to the resources of the HayMarket Theatre. Nowhere else can cornedv be so well
repiesented. 'Old Heads and Young Hearts' prepared the
play-goer for antithesis and repartee in the dialogue, and
strong contrasts in the characters.
W e w ere heartily glad,
however, that the audience recognized the manager's good
intentions,end justified the applause with which the curtain
eventually fell on the new plav.-—The Athenamm.
The pretensions of the comedy and its author, in this
instance, seem, to depend, in a very great degree,
on the dialogue, and to this we are disposed willingly to
accord no snail amount of merit. His dialogue is snowv,
superficial, occasionally brilliant. He surprises and pleases
too, by a happy allnsion or pointed phrase. The audience
were kept skilfully in suspense tiil the very close. T h e
peiforraers exerted themselves zealously to seeure the success
of the play, and this they undoubtedly achieved. As a
whole it went oilW e l l , and was uproariously applauded at
the conclusion. The piece is admirably produced, and has
every adventitious appliance fitted to aid'in giving reality and
effect to every scene. We fee! bound to add that the report
we hear of its nightly reception since, warrants the belief
that it will have a run that will repay the manager for its production ; while the acting of such performers as are engaged
in it must ensure the development ot whatever merit it
possesses.—Satirist.
Whatever name is given to the entertainment in five acts
produced here, its reception does not admit of doubt. It is
greatly successful. W e did not see it until Thursday, when,
in despite and defiance of the fog, we found the enjoyment
of a large audience clear and indisputable. Laughter was
hearty and unrestrained, and the curtain fell to peals of prolonged applause. The arrangements of the scene are all in
the best possible taste.—Examiner.

THE FIRST PART.
Entirely original, founded on the third and fonrth Books of " The Argonauties," a Poem, by the
late Apolloniua Rhodins, Esq.* principal Librarian to His Egyptian Majesty, Ptolemy E-ergetes,
Professor of Greek Poetry in the Royal College of Alexandria, & c , & c , and entitled

JASON I I COLCHIS

ASetes, King of Colchis, (Possessor of the original Golden Wlsece) Mr. JAMES BLAND,

Which may defy competition in any other Establishment, the Lessee has, regardless of expense, engaged

rendering at least fifty-nine male voices perfectly unnecessary.
The Stage, which has been constructed after the approved fashion of the revived Greek Theatre,
Will he partially raised, but the prices of admission remain exactly as before. It is also requisite to
observe, that a frequent change of scene being contrary to the usage of the Ancient Greek Drama/

rendering at least fifty-nine male voices perfectly unnecessary.

NOTICE
